issue.title: rclone 1.54 version compress function demo remote is S3

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body: Could you please share one simple demo for how to use the 1.54 COMPRESS function?

body:
Looking at the integration test config I can see a single test remote for `compress`, which is probably using a local base. Are you planning to test it using other backends, like S3 or Drive?
(https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/fstest/test_all/config.yaml#L89)

I'll look into this. 

>Looking at the integration test config I can see a single test remote for compress, which is probably using a local base. Are you planning to test it using other backends, like S3 or Drive?
>(https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/fstest/test_all/config.yaml#L89)

Should've probably done this all along.

I think this is because the compress backend embeds the upstream object but doesn't override the Hash() function

https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/db2c38b21bb70b951e7d9a35bf394b39b798c93f/backend/compress/compress.go#L946-L948

issue.title: compress: fix remotes without PutStream & ObjectInfo wrapping.

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
Quick postmortem here: #4928 was caused by the wrapped ObjectInfo actually returning the checksum & size of the uncompressed object which obviously differs from the compressed object actually upload (duh!). Since we cannot know the checksum & size of the compressed object beforehand there is really no useful information that can be returned here.

While wondering how I didn't catch that beforehand I found a second bug.  Prior to https://github.com/rclone/rclone/commit/886b3abac17404910d89192fae74cdec47515702 I was using operations.Rcat() instead of put when uploading compressed files which had the side effect of masking this bug since it didn't make use of the ObjectInfo wrapping. Well, turns out there was a reason I was using operations.Rcat() there since we cannot know the size of the compressed file beforehand (second duh!) this was required to be able to support underlying remotes without put stream. I've now implemented a Jottacloud-MD5 style workaround for this that spools the file to ram or disk to determine it's size and uploads using normal Put.

I'd also strongly suggest adding additional integration tests for this remote similar chunker. At least one non-local file-based & one bucket based remote would probably be a good idea here @ncw.
